Data Scientist

I’m a data scientist and web development enthusiast with a passion for teaching and making knowledge accessible to everyone. Guided by curiosity, creativity and a drive to empower others through learning, I’m always building, exploring, and sharing.


🌟 Professional Interests


Since November 2023, I have held the position of Temporary Teaching and Research Associate (Attaché Temporaire d’Enseignement et de Recherche) at the University of Lille. I actively contribute to multiple academic programs, notably the BUT in Data Science and various Professional Bachelor’s degrees, delivering courses across diverse topics.
My teaching portfolio covers a wide spectrum of statistical methodologies, from Descriptive analysis to advanced statistical modeling. I design and lead lectures, tutorials, and hands-on sessions employing industry-standard tools such as R, Python, Excel and SAS to equip students with practical data analysis and programming skills.
Beyond classroom teaching, I have successfully supervised numerous student projects, guiding them through the application of statistical techniques and data science principles to real-world datasets. This mentorship fosters critical thinking and practical problem-solving, ensuring student success in their academic and professional pursuits.
My research is centered on the analysis of large-scale and complex spatial data, where I develop and implement innovative statistical models tailored to address challenging problems in biostatistics and related fields. I have authored peer-reviewed publications that propose novel methodologies for spatial data analysis, reflecting my commitment to advancing the scientific community’s understanding of complex data structures.

Automatic geomorphological mapping using ground truth data with coverage sampling and random forest algorithms.

Journal: Earth Science Informatics
Date: 2024-06-26
Authors: Paul A. L. Faye, Elodie Brunel, Thomas Claverie, Solym Manou-Abi Sophie Dabo-Niang.
This work develops an automated framework for creating marine geomorphological maps using statistical learning. By leveraging bathymetric data and terrain attributes, it applies clustering algorithms to identify ground truth locations and a random forest model for classification. The study evaluates the impact of DBM resolution, sample size, and sampling methods on map quality. Results show the framework produces high-quality maps, with the best performance achieved using a 100m DBM resolution, 200 samples, and complexity-dependent sampling, yielding a 90% match with the reference map.



 Figure. Geyser is an atoll in the Western Indian ocean, specifically located in the northern Mozambique channel between Mayotte and the Gloriosos Islands and covering approximately 268 km2. A Bathymetry data (in meters) collected by LIDAR technology and provided by Hydrography and Oceanography Service of the Navy (SHOM). B Geomorphologic structure identified for the Geyser atoll, as a part of the EPICURE project (Roos et al. 2017).
